2. Application ContextÂ¶

2.1 Physical setupÂ¶

  • Sensors: measure cart position \(x\), pendulum angles \(\theta_1\) and \(\theta_2\), and the corresponding velocities \(\dot{x}\), \(\dot{\theta}_1\) and \(\dot{\theta}_2\). The implementation orders these six signals as \([x,\theta_1,\theta_2,\dot{x},\dot{\theta}_1,\dot{\theta}_2]\) when forming the state vector. This naming follows the code and I/O contracts (see io_contracts.csv) and eliminates the ambiguous subscript _c used in earlier drafts. Measurements are sampled at 100Â Hz, corresponding to a 10Â ms sampling period, and form the state vector for control. This rate matches the default simulation time step dt = 0.01 defined in config.yamlÂ [CIT-043]. Individual controller implementations may specify a smaller internal dt (e.g., 0.001Â s for certain superâ€‘twisting or adaptive variants), but the baseline configuration and logging operate on a 10Â ms period. The sensors are quantised with step sizes configured in config.yaml (0.01Â rad for angles and 0.0005Â m for position)Â [CIT-044]; these finite resolutions introduce small quantisation noise but do not affect the ordering or unit definitions. In addition to quantisation, additive white measurement noise is applied in software: the sensors section of config.yaml specifies a standard deviation of 0.005Â rad for angle measurements (angle_noise_std) and 0.001Â m for the cart position (position_noise_std)Â [CIT-046]. These Gaussian noise levels are injected at each 10Â ms sample. In hardwareâ€‘inâ€‘theâ€‘loop (HIL) experiments the hil.sensor_noise_std parameter controls additional transmission noise (default zero).

  • Actuator: a linear force actuator applies a horizontal force \(F\in[-150,150]\,\text{N}\) to the cart. The actuator saturates at the specified max_force in config.yamlÂ [CIT-045].

  • Plant: the doubleâ€‘inverted pendulum on a cart has nominal parameters defined in config.yaml. These include the cart mass \(m_0=1.5\,\text{kg}\), pendulum masses \(m_1=0.2\,\text{kg}\) and \(m_2=0.15\,\text{kg}\), lengths \(l_1=0.4\,\text{m}\) and \(l_2=0.3\,\text{m}\), centreâ€‘ofâ€‘mass distances \(l_{1,\mathrm{com}}=0.2\,\text{m}\) and \(l_{2,\mathrm{com}}=0.15\,\text{m}\), inertias \(I_1=2.65\times10^{-3}\,\text{kgÂ·m}^2\) and \(I_2=1.15\times10^{-3}\,\text{kgÂ·m}^2\), gravitational acceleration \(g=9.81\,\text{m/s}^2\), and viscous friction coefficients \(b_c=0.2\), \(b_1=0.005\) and \(b_2=0.004\)ã€359986572901373â€ screenshotã€‘. Earlier drafts omitted the friction values; they are essential for accurate modelling and match the defaults in the configuration. Photos and diagrams of the setup can be placed in the img/ folder.

2.2 Constraints & disturbancesÂ¶

Before turning to the tuning bounds, note that the nominal physical parameters stated aboveâ€”cart mass, pendulum masses, lengths, centreâ€‘ofâ€‘mass distances, inertias and friction coefficientsâ€”are taken directly from the physics section of config.yamlÂ [CIT-063].

These minimum and maximum values are not arbitrary Â±10Â % variations; they originate from the pso.tune section of config.yaml and define the search domain used by the PSO tuner when jointly optimising controller gains and selected physical parameters. Each parameter is sampled uniformly within its specified range when tuning is enabled.

Other sources of disturbance include quantisation noise and sensor noise. The sensors have finite resolution (0.01Â rad for angles and 0.0005Â m for position), and these quantisation steps are specified as quantization_angle and quantization_position in config.yamlÂ [CIT-044]. Additive measurement noise levels are defined in the sensors section of the configuration and are set to 0.005Â rad for angles and 0.001Â m for position by default; these values mirror the angle_noise_std and position_noise_std entries in config.yamlÂ [CIT-046]. Unmodelled higherâ€‘order dynamics and external perturbations may also act on the system. The PSO tuner and robustness tests vary the physical parameters within the above bounds and inject sensor noise and disturbances to evaluate controller performance under uncertainty.

2.3 Objectives â†” KPIsÂ¶

  • Objective: track cart position reference quickly while keeping both pendulums upright and minimising control energy.

    • KPIs:

      • Settling time: \(t_s < 2\,\text{s}\)Â (KPIâ€‘001)

      • Overshoot: \(M_p < 10Â \%\)Â (KPIâ€‘002)

      • IAE: minimised over the simulation horizon (KPIâ€‘003)

      • Stability margins: phase margin â‰¥ 45Â°, gain margin â‰¥ 6Â dB (KPIâ€‘004)
